More than a dozen hospitals across Great Britain declared major incidents this past week.
They canceled all nonemergency operations and called in extra staff to cope with overcrowded emergency rooms.
And still, the back log in waiting rooms is growing.
Vicki Barker reports from London.
(SOUNDBITE OF NEWS REPORT)
Amy Dickinson with us today from Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, which must be decked out with Halloween festoonings.

Well, there's nothing quite like small town at Halloween, especially in the Northeast, where fall has really descended, where you've been having this spectacular full moon and all I can say is hu-wa-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha…
It's going to…
(Soundbite of laughter)
Really great and scary.
I was driving to my hometown today and I caught my neighbor out front digging a fresh grave in his front yard.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And I'm from the Northeast, and I was scared every time when it's too warm for Halloween.
It should be nippy.
Oh, yeah.
And we're going to have the - where I am, we will have the absolutely perfect conditions for Halloween tomorrow night - upper 40s, really crisp and clear, full stars in the sky.
It's really going to be great.
But one thing I'm concerned about is as usual - you know, remember when Halloween used to be great?
It was all about kids.
It was all about being scary.
The grown ups, it seems - like everything else - the grown ups came along and kind of ruined it.
Halloween is now the second most commercial holiday after Christmas.
It is - it's been completely - almost completely appropriated by adults.
And here's what I love.
We, adults, we will let out kids go to see ""Saw III"" and yet…
Four, this weekend.
Yeah.
…Four, and yet, we were really nervous about the scary costumes that might - they might choose to wear.
At my local school, they've decided not to have a costume day but to have a pajama day.
Because costumes are too scary?
Costumes can be both scary and they can be inappropriate.
As you pointed out, lots of girls lately seem to want to - going kind of a sexy direction, which is - people don't like, and they shouldn't.
So, and it's - basically, the costume thing is hard to control, and so schools are trying to control it by basically…
Ducking the issue.
…ducking it.
Yeah.
Well, we'll take calls on any or all of those questions with Ask Amy: 800-989-8255.
Here's an e-mail we got from Susan(ph) in McHenry, Illinois.
What's Amy's opinion on how old is too old for trick-or-treating?
We've gone through this disagreement for years, one child after another, as they reached the age that we think is too old for this activity.
Well, I love this question.
I actually have been dealing with this in my column.
I got a wonderful letter from a 14-year-old who said that he mother had cut her off from trick-or-treating this year.
And so, I ran a letter.
I actually feel that Halloween - the younger kids go out in a wave, between maybe 5:00 and 6:30.
Mm-hmm.
That's all about the little kids.
I feel like after that, if there's candy left, I'll give to anyone.
And I love actually having - my whole deal is you have to dress up in a costume.
Right.
Don't come to my house just hand out.
I really want to see teens dressed in costumes.
But when I read - when I ran a letter, I heard back from a lot of teens who had found really creative ways to get around the whole trick-or-treating thing.

One way is to - one teen wrote in and said that she and her friends dressed up and they did kind of a canned-food drive, collecting food for - that they then took to a shelter, and in the course of doing that also received a lot of candy.
I love that.
Yeah.
But that's a very productive way to do it, you know?
The rule that we had in our house is if you're not willing to dress in a really dumb costume, then you're too old.
Well, see, that's the thing.

Well, then when I ran the letter about teens who had chosen to do kind of useful things at UNICEF, et cetera, I got a letter - actually, I got it yesterday from a teenager who basic - and I love this letter because this kid said, you know what?
I'm going to go out.
I'm going to come trick-or-treating.
And if you don't give me candy - basically, it was kind of veiled threats.
And I e-mailed this kid back and I said, what are you going to - you're going to knock over a candy shop if I don't give you candy, you know?
But actually, that's what I love about Halloween.
I love how a little - everything gets a little out of control.
Mm-hmm.
